												This game is brilliant. It has one main strength that makes it a true gem, but it might be often overlooked: this game has two faces really.At first glance it seems like a very casual but pleasant puzzle platformer. The levels are fun, they require a little bit of figuring out but nothing too complicated. You can pretty much play through the main 100 levels of this game like that without even realising there's more to it. This makes the game appeal to those gamers who just enjoy to chill out.But there's a lot more this game is hiding... As you'll find out if you try earning fancier flowers, which requires completing levels within a strict time limit. You'll soon realise that for many levels those basic obvious methods of solving them that you used so far don't really work if you want to be fast enough. You suddenly learn the game has a number of undocumented features... little tricks you can do that may even look like exploits, allowing you to skip parts of the levels... But no! You're actually supposed to do all that! Those tricks aren't easy to pull off and getting good enough times is really challenging. Suddenly the casual chill-out game becomes a test of skill comparable to Super Meat Boy. And if you manage to get through all that too and you think you're done... Nope! Super-hard bonus levels are unlocked. If you manage to 100% this game, you're really really good.This all makes Offspring Fling a great little game for both casual gamers and the most hardcore players. I'm very positively surprised, because initially when I started playing it, it seemed very generic and not standing out in any way. I saw very simplistic graphics and simple puzzles like in million other flash games published on various websites. I was wrong. I was completely wrong. Please take my word for it and don't get the wrong impression like I did. This game is a true masterpiece.

												100 levels of platforming and baby throwing of cuteness. You play as a mother Pikachu thing that needs to get her babies out the door and then get out herself. To do this, you can pick them up, throw them to the left or right, jump, hit switches and so on. You can even put them down on switches or on door blocks so when you hit the switch, the door holds open. When thrown, the babies go across the screen until they hit something then they fall. That lets them be used to hit triggers from far away. When carrying a baby, you can't jump as high, nor can you fit through small gaps as you normally can when not carrying them. If one baby doesn't make it, then you merely restart the level with the quick restart button.Even if the music and art style weren't top notch, this would be a great puzzle game. Most every level is only a single screen and you will blow through 40+ levels before you reach a real challenge. Not every level is meant to be a challenge though. Some are very simple to show new techniques and others are just fun in general. Each completed level unlocks others, but you can go in order and just keep playing the next level. It adds to the flow of the game. The levels are quick, simple, engaging and rewarding; all with a dose of adorability. Each level has a par time and keeps track of your best time. In fact the game shows you your ghost when you replay levels that you have completed.Eventually, throwable rocks, adorable enemies, breakable blocks, crayon colored deadly traps and angled trampolines that change thrown baby directions get added to the mix. Throwing your babies into the adorable enemies is a way to stun them. Its a good way to keep amping up the challenge and diversity between level to level. Remember baby, mama loves you, no matter how much she throws you against the wall or into the face of a giant lizard.This game goes by quick, and to pad it out, there is a level editor, along with the ability to download countless other levels made by other users. There's a lot of engaging fun here, but it all goes by so quick and virtually effortless that it feels like there's no reason to come back. 5 minutes of play can complete 10 levels.

												Offspring Fling is the most fun I've ever had throwing babies. That's partially because I don't get to throw babies very often, but also because it does what it does quite well. Every puzzle game needs to make the most of whatever portion of the genre it carves out and this title does just that, forcing you to push your understanding and mastery of its mechanics to their limits. What it lacks in scale it more than makes up in heart and polish, which are often in short supply on the platforming side.I'm not sure what you play as in Offspring Fling, but whatever it is it's adorable and has tons of tiny adorable babies. Some damn dinosaur thing comes through and scatters them though, so you've got to help your bunny-mama-thing round up her childrens. This happens over a hundred levels that are mostly single-screen puzzles but pack plenty of tricks and traps into that space. Along the way you'll deal with deadly pits, switch blocks, monsters, and other hazards to complicate saving your little ones.The main mechanic of the game is throwing your kids around, unsurprisingly. Pressing down next to one of your tiny offspring hefts them over your head, and pressing C pitches them in a straight line either right or left. You have to get them and yourself to the exit and the easiest way to do that is to chuck them through the door, but of course it's never that simple. Holding a baby raises the height of your character, slows them down, and limits their jump, meaning that you have to strategize how you move them around and make the most of your throws. This is even more important in levels with three or four offspring to transport.Very quickly you'll start coming across levels where a simple obstruction like a one-block space or a slightly too-tall wall force you to come up with complex maneuvers to get past. They're clever puzzles, ones that appear simple but build difficulty outward as you keep running into little snags in your plans. The puzzles that introduce new gimmicks like pits and switches do an excellent job of easing you into dealing with them as well, so the overall difficulty curve is quite smooth. Be aware that much of the challenge in Offspring Fling is based on timing and reflexes, though. Some puzzles will require you to outrun enemies or traps, or catch a baby in mid-flight to prevent its heart-wrenching demise.With timing challenges come timers, and it's here that Offspring Fling allows you to go as hard as you want. Beating a level at all earns you a flower, needed to unlock further sets of levels. But each level also has a target time that requires an optimized solution and earns you an additional gold flower. Early on these will come easily but soon start to get away from you, forcing some brain-wracking to earn. And then, if you're a true offspring-flinger, you can go for the rainbow flowers which are only awarded for beating the level in the fastest time possible. These are absurdly hard to get on anything that isn't a tutorial level and sometimes require far more clever and less obvious solutions to reach.It's all wound up in an adorably fluffy package with some Yoshi's Island-style sketch graphics and pleasing sound design. Honestly between the sharp puzzles and charming aesthetic there's not much holding it back, aside from the lack of story depth. Be warned, though, I wasn't able to get it running on my Windows 10 system so you might have to pass it over if you're fully upgraded. Aside from that it's an easy sell to fans of puzzles, cute games, and throwing babies. And everyone likes at least ONE of those.

												If there is one thing Offspring Fling has going for it, it's charm. A childlike sensibility embodies every aspect of the game, from the beautiful crayon aesthetic to the heartfelt premise of a mother that has somehow misplaced here extremely numerous children. The music also does a good job at setting it apart, mixing classic 8-Bit sounds with classical instruments to great effect.It's a shame then that the gameplay doesn't reach the same level, and in fact I found it rather dull and inconsistently challenging. This is mainly because of the jumping mechanics, which feel very much inspired by Nintendo's Kirby games (your character's appearance shares a striking similarity to him as well). They are simply too floaty and impressive for a game built so heavily around timing, and made some of the otherwise basic levels frustrating to complete. The spotty controller support didn't help, as anyone that has tried to play a platformer using a keyboard should understand.If you can get past the controls you'll find a lightweight, mostly enjoyable puzzle platformer that never quite reaches its full potential, and is best appreciated in bite sized sessions to combat its somewhat repetitive design. If you are looking for a more well rounded experience however, you will probably be better served elsewhere.

												* I guess i'll add my opinion about level 101-120 since i just beat it today. My playtime: 32.9h (based on steam, 100% achievement)19h (based on steam, 100 blue/99 golden/99 rainbow flower)Comparing it to Angry Birds:Blue flower = 1 starGolden flower =  2 starsRainbow flower = 3 starsGrindy Achievement: No.Optional Achievement: Yes (5 achievements).Difficult Achievement: Yes (8 achievements. Seriously, this game is hard).Developer Response: No (last response is in 14 Nov 2015, but you'll get a response in around 24h if you email the dev).IntroOffspring Fling! is a difficult platformer game about throwing chickens. I said difficult because it's hard to collect the flowers and some levels will only be unlocked after you collect the flowers (and those levels are harder than the rest of the levels). Each level will take less than one minute, except level 100 because of the long "cutscene" (but you can do it in less than 1 minute). Your time in each level determines which flower you'll get. Although the blue and golden flower might be easy to get, you can't say the same to the rainbow flower. The rainbow flower, which also can be called as dev times because it's the dev's time herself, is quite insane. Not only you need to finish the levels quicker (even with a difference in just one millisecond), you also have to master some tricks to do it faster.I was planning to finish the game as soon as i get 100 golden flowers because i can't seem to get the rainbow flowers on the first few levels after several tries, but i ended up realizing that i can get them after doing a few levels. Some levels have more than one way to finish with; while some levels can be completed faster with an easier way, some levels can be completed faster with a harder way. Besides, you'll understand and master a few techniques as you play.GraphicsThe graphics in this game is very cute. If you like pixels, you'll definitely love this. The pixel art is very nice to see, although the main menu might be confusing because the icons are not common.MusicFor a difficult game where you need to hear the same music over and over, you'll need to have a great music which won't make the players tired listening to it and Offspring Fling! does a good job with it. Perhaps one of the reason i'm still playing the game despite of the difficulty is because of the awesome music.ControlsI have to say that the controls are terrible. Especially if you are aiming for the dev times. Even the cursor is very slow (luckily, you'll only need mouse in the menu). There are delays between actions: jumping, throwing, picking up chickens--all of them. You'll need to time them right to do it. Some tricks require you to do a combination between actions, and it's not as easy as you think. One example is jumping + picking up chicken trick, which will need some time to get used with. You'll be raging everytime on your first few hour because of the "stupid controls", but you'll get used to it. At the next few hours, you'll realize that the "stupid controls" are not the thing that you need to rage about, it's the "seem-to-be-impossible-to-beat dev times" instead.There are some design which you'll need to abuse to beat the dev times. You can actually jump a few seconds before falling on an edge, and you can actually flip a switch twice if you are fast enough. Although the second one won't be used that much, you'll have to abuse the first time a lot. There is even a level (level 44, uppercut), where people finish it with sick reaction time, as in.. jumping, picking up chicken, throwing, landing on an edge, jumping after you reach the edge, picking up the chicken (again), and throwing it in a split second. Luckily, the trick is not needed to beat the stage.My opinion about the last 20 levelsI was stuck in a level before because i didn't know that you can boost your speed while running in a small passage by banging the roof. Because of that, i have to stop playing the game for like 3 months before i start picking it up again. This makes me forgot most of the techniques, not to mention the slow down button (triggered with F12), which i usually used to play the levels, isn't working. I ended up thinking that it's impossible to beat the game, which just become possible today.After emailing the dev with a hope that she'll fix this "bug", i only got a response with no luck in recovering my slow down button. She can't seem to reproduce the issue and said that she'll give me a build which has different key binding for the slow down. It's been a week and i haven't heard more from her. Luckily, i have already learned to play the game without that button in a hard way. Just fyi, the button strangely worked today and i found out that i can't seem to parry with it.After playing the levels which are considered "very hard" by the others, i found out that those are true, especially during my ~3 months hiatus. I forgot most of the controls, resulting in doing trial and error for most levels until i somehow get used to it. Levels 101-110 will test your ability from the existing techniques, while level 111-120, the real hell, will introduce a new parry technique which have to be applied in a hard way. It'll be extremely hard if you didn't use the second character. However, i have to say that the last 20 levels (especially the last 10), doesn't feel the same way as the first 100 levels. Sure, the game is more difficult, but i feel like i have to do the same thing over and over until i do things right, not because i'm not fast enough. This bores me quickly, especially when you die right after you started. In the first 100 levels, i feel the "one more level" feeling as i finished the game. However, for the last 20 levels, i got the "if i fail again, it's time to rest" feel.After finishing all levels, i ended up knowing more technical things, like how you should parry when you are below the enemy (if you're curious, the answer is you don't, because you have to figure out whether you're in the left or right position from the enemy's center), how to press keys after free falling, and more.Well, this has become long, but tbh, aside from the satisfaction that i finally can get rid of this game and how lucky i am to finish this game, i don't really feel anything after finishing this game unlike how i did after i beat level 100.Pros:- 100+ levels- Technique-based (or luck based)- Short levels (less than 1 min)- 3 characters (2 unlockable characters)Cons:- Strict delay between actions- Requires to abuse a lot of "techniques" just to defeat the dev times- No in-game tutorial for the techniquesSummaryThis is a difficult platforming game. A casual gamer might be able to play it (by not caring with the time), but some levels and secrets can only be unlocked if you try very hard.Should you buy this game?Yes.If you are a hardcore gamer who like difficult games, this can be a challenge for you. I won't recommend it for casual gamers though, because you'll miss a lot of content.

												If you ever sit at the computer, re-watching your favorite tv series, or chatting with your friends, and you need a game that will occupy you, but won't take all of your concentration, this is it.I used to play minesweeper or free-cell on days like that. Now I play Offspring Fling!It's a simple platformer, with numerous levels, puzzles, and a variety of obstacles. The goal? You are a small, furry creature, whose offspring (and a lot of it) got scattered all over. You need to find your babies, and transport them to safety (on your head, or by throwing them around). It's super cute, and the levels can get super difficult. It requires a lot of thinking and skill, and timing. But it's a small, simple game that you can pause at any second, so it doesn't take up your whole mind. I usually play it while skyping with someone, or chatting on facebook.Plus it's super duper cheap. Or at least it was, when I got it.The graphics are old school 16 bit. And there are OVER 100 levels. The soundtrack? As adorable as the game.So if you're looking for something small, simple, and fun to do while you're waiting for a video to buffer, or something. Go for it.

												Well this is certainly a cute game, but I feel like the creator(s) were fooling around during the development of this game when it comes to some of the technical aspects. No option to change resolution or set the game in full screen (I may be wrong). The game had stable performance at least, no crashes or bugs or glitches.Game play is simple, fling those offspring into doors, each level is pretty short and you don't have to play many of them to reach the ending, especially if you perform well. At most there are around 5 of those little guys (don't remember how big the largest level is) you have to throw around avoiding hazards. The graphics are cute, but are too derivative of something like Bubble Bobble and Kirby. The music is forgettable but appropriate for the game’s style.The game just doesn't stand out, as competent as it is crafted. The best part is completing a stage under time, it’s like eating a burger, satisfactory, just enough to keep you going to the next stage. The core mechanics don't necessarily change, nor do you acquire powers that change dramatically the flow of the game, so it's you having to better your skills as you progress, a style of play I like.The game would’ve been stronger if the levels somewhat longer, more distinct, and more dangerous, forcing the player’s attention more. Concentrating on beating times makes sense with the current design of the game fortunately, but I feel it may have limited the potential the game had.I find myself lukewarm towards the game, played it, completed it, forgot about it and that's the biggest sin a game can commit in my opinion.(Any mistakes in my text may be attributed to the fact that English is not my first language, sorry if it makes this review hard to read)

This is a solid platformer.There's nothing much to say more than that, really. Offspring Fling is about clearing relatively small levels, with numerous puzzles within each one, as fast as you can -- while using your "young" as objects to be carried to the exist, and to fling them across the level to operate levers and trigger-weights. The speed and movement is solid, the controls are responsive for the most part, and the game isn't as linear in solving the levels as one might think. It suprisingly has a bit of depth to it.Now, the depth of the game first shows itself with the dev's 'ghost', the recording of how the dev beat the level so quickly, in basically that... It cheats. It uses exploits in the game, to clear the game faster, like jumping constantly within a corridor with a short ceiling, to cut the animation short which boost's one speed a bit. And that's not the only exploit there is, although I haven't found any more than 2.The game becomes more interesting that way, it builds a form of 'special techniques' that allows you to play in a specialized manner. And unlike, say, Dustforce, it's pretty easy to learn how to use them.I like this game, it's concise and simple, yet with enough depth to make you play the entire game more than once.

												Offspring Fling has brought many nice surprises to me, starting from the first moments I played it.  It's a puzzle-platformer with adorable visuals, smart gameplay, and challenging puzzles, all without deterring the casual experience.I bought this game with a Humble Bundle, mostly because I wanted some the more expensive deals I would get from buying the bundle, and there Offspring Fling sat in my library, uninstalled, until those goshdarn trading cards showed up, encouraging me to give it a shot.  It was during the opening credits that I suddenly noticed: this game was made by Kyle Pulver!  This isn't the first Kyle Pulver game I've played, and I think I'm going to start paying more attention to the guy.  He first caught my attention back in high school as I was looking for tips on how to create my own indie games.  I stumbled upon one of his other games called BONESAW and said to myself "yes, this guy gets it."  The controls were intuitive and fun, the story was minimalistic, and the gameplay, while reminding me retro beat-em-ups like Double Dragon, blew them all out of the water!Now, I can safely say that Kyle Pulver hasn't lost his touch.  The game is adorable with its visuals, and brutal in its gameplay.  The puzzles are that special kind of retro-challenging, but the controls are spot on and never frustrating.  To 100% the game is a gaming challenge equal to that of some of gamings greatest achievements, and recommended only to completely insane individuals (like myself).  It's the kind of unique experience that reminds you of a simpler time in gaming, where gameplay innovation and a solid setting were enough to make you undergo the toughest challenges you've ever faced.  Great work, Mr. Pulver!

												A fantastic platformer filled with charm, replayability and some dead-hard time challenges. You must navigate your little yellow Pika babies to safety (by throwing them violently across the world) and then get there yourself. A plethora of enemies, switches and hazardous ooze stand in your way.The first so many levels introduce you to the game quite comfortably, but the difficulty soon ramps up. Or rather, not the actual difficulty of completing levels, but the satisfaction of completing levels FAST and attaining Gold and Rainbow flowers.In truth, almost all of the levels are fairly easy to complete, but the true underlying challenge here is to complete each level in a quick time, which earns you a Gold flower. If you complete the level faster than the time the developer set, you earn a juicy and illustrious Rainbow flower. However, almost ALL of the rainbow flowers are very difficult to earn. Patience, some key tricks you can perform which you will need to learn and master, and downright skill are needed to rack up all 110 Rainbow flowers.If you are a fan of puzzle-platforming and have some keen quick reflexes, this is the perfect game!The graphics and music are suitably charming, and service the game perfectly!

												Puzzle-platformingOffspring Fling is a puzzle- plaftforming game released in 2012 by Kyle Pulver.The plot serves as justification for the gameplay. You play as a mother (of forest creatures resembling a certain pokemon) who has lost all of her children after a monster attack. The mother now has to search the woods and retrieve all of her lost children.Gameplay is a mainly puzzle solving with some platforming elements. There are various levels (over 100). At the start of each one you will see where you (the mother), the children, exit, buttons and monsters are located on the screen. In order to win each level, you need to collect all the children and deliver them to the exit, which is done by walking up to the children and pick up each one and then either, drop, shoot or carry them to the door. For each child you pick up, your weight increases, which decreases your jump height.The puzzle element comes into play when you have to figure out how to reach the all the children, which are trapped behind barriers or hard to reach places. Puzzles are generally solved by dropping your children on buttons (to remove barriers and decrease weight) which will allow you to reach the other kids. There are also traps and monsters which will kill you and the children. Should you or any child die, the level immediately ends and you have to restart. You and your children have only 1 life and no health, so anything dangerous will kill you instantlly.There is also a timer which only starts when you move your character, allowing you time to plan out your movements beforehand. In order to unlock new levels you need to beat the recorded time for the level.Audio is quite nice. The back ground music is cheerful and suits this game well. There is no voice acting. The sound FX for jumping and finishing a level sound similar to 'Mario' games.Levels are quite unique, with the placements of children, obstacles and the mother, no levels look or feel the same.Graphics are decent. The colours and 2D artstyle present a cheerful atmosphere.If you are looking for a puzzle game with some plaftfroming, this game will not dissapoint.

												Offspring Fling is a casual 2D game that consists of competing with yourself to beat a level quickly. It takes a lot of tries, but once I get that great time and that golden flower I feel extremely satisfied and proud. If you're a casual gamer but like a bit of a challenge, you should take a look at Offspring Fling.The music was the first thing that took me, its beautifully simple and immersive. The only problem I had with it was the fact that it loops the same song and it can get repetitive. The plot of the game was introduced with pictures rather than words, which fits the game's style well. The controls are what make this timed platformer up, at first they feel unnatural and forced, but if you focus on where your character is at all times you start to adapt to them. The game's nature is simple yet competitive, you try to score a better time than a replay of yourself, that's it. The graphics are a unique simplistic 2D that also fits this game's theme perfectly, however it would help to make this platformer's graphics sharper from a gameplay perspective. The gameplay is fun for a while, but being that the game sticks with the same concepts for long periods of time make it tedious replaying the same thing over and over striving for the best score.Offspring fling does very well at what it's shooting for, however if the devs would have introduced more game mechanics at a quicker rate, the game would be much better. The controls could be smoothed, and some new music would be well deserved. My overall score of this game is a 6.5/10, slightly above average.

												Offspring Fling has brought many nice surprises to me, starting from the first moments I played it.  It's a puzzle-platformer with adorable visuals, smart gameplay, and challenging puzzles, all without deterring the casual experience.I bought this game with a Humble Bundle, mostly because I wanted some the more expensive deals I would get from buying the bundle, and there Offspring Fling sat in my library, uninstalled, until those goshdarn trading cards showed up, encouraging me to give it a shot.  It was during the opening credits that I suddenly noticed: this game was made by Kyle Pulver!  This isn't the first Kyle Pulver game I've played, and I think I'm going to start paying more attention to the guy.  He first caught my attention back in high school as I was looking for tips on how to create my own indie games.  I stumbled upon one of his other games called BONESAW and said to myself "yes, this guy gets it."  The controls were intuitive and fun, the story was minimalistic, and the gameplay, while reminding me retro beat-em-ups like Double Dragon, blew them all out of the water!Now, I can safely say that Kyle Pulver hasn't lost his touch.  The game is adorable with its visuals, and brutal in its gameplay.  The puzzles are that special kind of retro-challenging, but the controls are spot on and never frustrating.  To 100% the game is a gaming challenge equal to that of some of gamings greatest achievements, and recommended only to completely insane individuals (like myself).  It's the kind of unique experience that reminds you of a simpler time in gaming, where gameplay innovation and a solid setting were enough to make you undergo the toughest challenges you've ever faced.  Great work, Mr. Pulver!
